ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned about different ways of understanding the holocaust, such as functionalist vs intentionalist theories of how the holocaust happened, different problems that can be involved in the dissemination of victim testimony, how the Holocaust emerged as a conceptual category

I learned how to read primary sources and relate them to larger historical events. I also learned how the Holocaust, which I thought of as a very specific phenomenon, had more sides than I realized. It was the gas chambers but also peasants killing their neighbors with pitchforks. It was deeply anti-Semitic but also weirdly secular.

A major takeaway from the course is that, if you look at a variety of sources, it's really hard to put everything into a neat argument. It's so complex.
It was a good course for history majors because it developed skills in terms of reading and understanding sources such as testimonies
Learned a lot about the holocaust/how to read various forms of testimony through a critical lens.
Very in-depth insight into the historiography of the Holocaust. I developed skills in writing and discussion. Analysis of historiographic material globally as well.

Learned a lot of the history leading up to the Holocaust and during the Holocaust. We also learned about Holocaust testimony and discussed the meaning of testimony and why it differs from empirical evidence.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish this class had been slightly larger in order to facilitate more engagement but that wasn't anyone's fault! also think that from time to time we could've had guiding questions going into discussions, sometimes the emotional intensity and vastness of the subject matter felt daunting and it would've been helpful to limit our seminars a bit more

Professor Dean is a great seminar leader because she listens to what students have to say and is sincerely trying to have a conversation. The syllabus is also really strong: everything fits together.

It sometimes felt, however, that the stakes aren't high enough for people to fully engage with the class. Most people don't do most of the reading and, honestly, I didn't either. 

I think Professor Dean is so charitable that she sees every comment as an insight and never exposes people when they don't know about the reading and say things that are shallow. This is nice but also makes it easy to skate by.
Really liked Prof. Dean, thought she facilitated interesting discussions/knew a lot about the intricacies of the texts we read.

Strengths:
Intriguing and Insightful, lots of relevant and interesting material.
Strengths are that there is open discussion, with guidance from the professor, of the reading material for that week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, this is an incredibly important issue to take a class on especially now when there are only a few survivors left to give their testimonies.

Yes! Professor Dean is so sweet and knowledgeable. The topic is specific enough that you can really feel like you're learning. I also appreciated that I was able to focus on the content rather than constantly doing busywork.
Yes, Professor Dean is great and I had a great time in this class. It was by far the seminar at yale I have participated the most in and where Ive felt most at ease speaking my mind.

I'm a STEM major and so this was my first history/writing class I've taken in a few years - but because the course material was very self-contained and only required basic background knowledge I felt like I could participate fully in the discussions. Also, 2 papers is really not bad at all for a WR - would definitely recommend.
Yes - if you have a specific interest in Holocaust history.
Yes, I would recommend if you are interested in the material, especially because the final paper is quite open to the direction you want to take it in.
